tool.name: WildfireExposure

param.name: hazCheck
param.dialogReference: Use the reclassify tool to generate hazard fuels rasters from categorical vegetation data.

param.name: whicHaz
param.dialogReference: Create reclassified rasters for 100 meter hazard fuel values, 500 meters, or both.

param.name: input_raster
param.dialogReference: Input categorical vegetation dataset.

param.name: remap_table100
param.dialogReference: Load or manually enter Hazard Fuels remap table for 100 meter distance.

param.name: remap_table500
param.dialogReference: Load or manually enter Hazard Fuels remap table for 500 meter distance.

param.name: hazOutput100
param.dialogReference: Output location for 100 meter hazard fuels raster.

param.name: hazOutput500
param.dialogReference: Output location for 500 meter hazard fuels raster.

param.name: expCheck
param.dialogReference: Create wildfire exposure datasets from hazard fuels raster datasets.

param.name: whichExp
param.dialogReference: Create 100 meter wildfire exposure, 500 meter, or both.

param.name: input_haz100
param.dialogReference: Input file location for the 100 meter hazard fuels raster. Not needed if also creating hazard fuels rasters.

param.name: input_haz500
param.dialogReference: Input file location for the 500 meter hazard fuels raster. Not needed if also creating hazard fuels rasters.

param.name: expOutput100
param.dialogReference: Output file path for the 100 meter wildfire exposure raster.

param.name: expOutput500
param.dialogReference: Output file path for the 500 meter wildfire exposure raster.

param.name: combiCheck
param.displayname: Create combined Exposure Dataset using Buildings Dataset
param.dialogReference: Create combined wildfire exposure dataset from 100 meter and 500 meter exposure datasets and a building footprint layer. Areas within 500 meters of buildings will be assigned values from 100 meter exposure, areas outside 500 meters from buildings will be assigned values from 500 meter exposure data.

param.name: input_exp100
param.dialogReference: Input file location for the 100 meter exposure raster. Not needed if also creating exposure rasters.

param.name: input_exp500
param.dialogReference: Input file location for the 500 meter exposure raster. Not needed if also creating exposure rasters.

param.name: input_buildings
param.dialogReference:
Input building footprint dataset. Can be vector or raster dataset. The tool will assume a rasterized buildings layer has already been buffered to a distance of 500 meters around buildings. Vector datasets can be either already buffered to a distance of 500 meters, or just building footprints - the next step allows a user to buffer them to 500 meters. It is recommended to use a rasterized, buffered dataset created prior to running this tool for large areas.

The output from this tool is currently saved to the project geodatabase.

param.name: bufferCheck
param.dialogReference: If the vector building footprint dataset is not already buffered, this will run a buffer with a distance of 500 meters.

param.name: expOutputCombi
param.dialogReference: Output file path for the combined wildfire exposure dataset.

param.name: clipOutputs
param.dialogReference: Clip output datasets to the shape of a specified polygon. This will clip any output files from the hazard, exposure, or combined exposure steps, but can not be run alone. If datasets have already been generated, user can replicate this step by running the Extract by Mask geoprocessing tool with generated datasets and the specified polygon.

param.name: clipExtent
param.dialogReference: Polygon input layer to clip output datasets.

tool.summary:
This ArcGIS Python Toolbox, developed in collaboration with Dr. Jennifer Schmidt, Institute for Social and Economic Research (ISER) at the University of Alaska Anchorage, is designed to allow users to calculate wildfire hazard fuels and exposure values from gridded vegetation data, as described in:

Schmidt, J.I., Ziel, R.H., Calef, M.P. et al. Spatial distribution of wildfire threat in the far north: exposure assessment in boreal communities. Nat Hazards 120, 4901â€“4924 (2024). https://doi.org/10.1007/s11069-023-06365-4

The toolbox was designed for replicating the described exposure assessment, and expanding to additional areas, in a user-friendly and repeatable way.
tool.usage: Given an input gridded vegetation classification file, processing methods include the calculation of hazard fuels layers at 100 and 500 meter distances, exposure layers at 100 and 500 meter distances, and a combined exposure layer that assigns the values from the 100 meter exposure within a 500m buffer distance of a buildings layer, and the 500 meter exposure values outside those areas. Intermediate products are also created and saved, and the tool can use previously generated intermediate products as inputs to limit processing time.

dataIdInfo.idCredit: Geographic Information Network of Alaska (University of Alaska Fairbanks), Institute for Social and Economic Research (University of Alaska Anchorage)
